newsitem.title: JAPAN: China, US bases remain Japan's big foreign issues.
newsitem.headline: China, US bases remain Japan's big foreign issues.

text.p: Sprawling U.S. military bases on the small island of Okinawa and strained ties with China remain Japan's biggest foreign policy issues after general elections.

Neither was a decisive issue in Sunday's election, but Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, staying in command with 239 seats in the 500-seat Lower House of parliament, must deliver on the two problems quickly, government officials said.
"It's probably the worst state of relations with China since normalisation in 1978," a senior Foreign Ministry official said on Monday.
"The government is considering sending a special envoy to China, either former prime minister Noboru Takeshita or LDP adviser Masaharu Gotoda," the ministry official said.

Hashimoto must mend strained ties with China before he leaves for the Philippines in late November to attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit, where he is sure to come face to face with Chinese leader Jiang Zemin.

China was vexed at the election platform of Hashimoto's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), which said there was no room for negotiations over the disputed Senkaku Islands, Japanese-controlled islets in the East China Sea. Called the Diaoyus in Chinese, they are claimed by both China and Taiwan.
Last month, a Hong Kong activist drowned near the islands during a protest against a makeshift lighthouse erected by a Japanese ultra-nationalist group.
China also criticised Hashimoto's visit to the controversial Yasukuni war shrine in Tokyo in July. He was the first Japanese prime minister to visit the shrine since 1985.
Yasukuni enshrines Japan's 2.6 million war dead since the late 19th century, including Class-A war criminals such as World War Two leader General Hideki Tojo.
In Sunday's poll, Hashimoto's LDP increased its strength in the Lower House but was dealt a crushing defeat in Okinawa.

It won none of the three single-seat constituencies on Okinawa, where anti-Tokyo sentiment still runs high from a row over renewal of land leases for the U.S. bases. As much as 75 percent of U.S. military facilities in Japan are on Okinawa.

Last month, Okinawans returned a 90 percent "yes" vote in a local referendum supporting calls to cut U.S. military bases. The rape of an Okinawan schoolgirl by U.S. servicemen in September 1995 triggered widespread opposition to bases.
Okinawa and Shiga in central Japan were alone among Japan's 47 prefectures in not returning a single LDP candidate.
Under the old multi-seat system, the LDP had always held two of the five seats on Okinawa. A single-seat system was introduced in Sunday's poll.
In moves to form a working majority in parliament, the LDP started coalition talks on Monday with the Social Democrats, who have been very keen to cut back on U.S. bases on Okinawa.

Okinawa Governor Masahide Ota said on Monday: "We are at least delighted that some of our strong supporters, in both the LDP and the Social Democratic Party, to reduce the bases have been re-elected."
The clearest winner in Sunday's polls were the Communists, who campaigned for the total scrapping of U.S. bases. They won 26 seats compared with 15 in the outgoing chamber.

Next month, foreign and defence ministers from Japan and the United States are due to begin negotiations to rewrite military contingency plans under the 1960 U.S.-Japan Security Treaty. Okinawa will be high on the agenda.
